title: Polar Equation of Conic
text: For a conic with a focus at the origin, if the directrix is $$x=p$$ or $$x=-p$$, where p is a positive real number, and the eccentricity is a positive real number e, the conic has a polar equation $$r=\frac{e p}{1+e cos\left(\theta\right)}$$ or $$r=\frac{e p}{1-e cos\left(\theta\right)}$$ For a conic with a focus at the origin, if the directrix is $$y=p$$ or $$y=-p$$, where p is a positive real number, and the eccentricity is a positive real number e, the conic has a polar equation $$r=\frac{e p}{1+e sin\left(\theta\right)}$$ or $$r=\frac{e p}{1-e sin\left(\theta\right)}$$

title: Directrix
text: The directrix is $$x=-p$$. Which trigonometric function is in the denominator?

title: Polar Equation
text: Our polar equation takes the form $$r=\frac{e p}{1-e cos\left(\theta\right)}$$ as identified by the directrix $$x=-p$$.

title: Numerator
text: The numerator is the product of the eccentricity and the absolute of the directrix, |p|. What is the numerator?

title: Eccentricity
text: The eccentricity is the magnitude of the coefficient of the trigonometric function in the denominator. The sign of the coefficient follows the sign of the directrix, $$x=-1$$. Thus, what is the coefficient of the trigonometric function?
